prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection and Characterization of Sources in Ophiuchus
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Use the 1.3mm continuum to detect the dust emission from material in a circumstellar disk and/or inner envelope associated with a VeLLO. The emission can be used to estimate the mass of material in the disk or inner envelope. This material represents the reservoir of material that is likely to be accreted in the next 10,000 years and indicates the likely nature of the VeLLO.
Use the CO J=2-1 line to detect the outflow. The outflow confirms the VeLLO status of the source. A background AGN is expected to have a much broader CO line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the CO J=2-1 line observation, we have chosen a velocity resolution of 0.3 km/sec which is sufficient for the outflow detection and resolving the core line width. The expected CO line sensitivity, ~15 mJy/beam/channel, is sufficient based on both our recent ALMA data and past detection levels from IRAM, SMA, and CARMA. Furthermore, we wish to keep uniform spectral resolution with our successful Cycle 2 observations.

The compact configuration was chosen because we are interested in searching for envelope and disk emission and identifying the outflow. Both the outflow and envelope likely have low surface brightness; therefore, the larger synthesized beam is desirable, as well as the sensitivity to spatial structures up to 10". While the disk is expected to be unresolved in our observations, resolution of the disk and detailed separation of the envelope and disk are not necessary to accomplish our science goals. This is primarily a detection and broad characterization experiment. Furthermore, we wish to keep uniform spatial resolution with our successful Cycle 2 observations.
Because we require spatial scales up to only 10" to characterize the inner envelope and because we are not fully mapping potential outflows, simply detecting them if present, we do not requir e ACA observations.

The time request for the survey is set by the continuum sensitivity requirement of 0.1 mJy/beam at the distance of Ophiuchus (125 pc; de Geus et al. 1989). Using existing MIPS 24 and/or 70 micron detections of VeLLOs in Ophiuchus, we used the radiative transfer models in the DIRT on-line tool (Wolfire & Cassinelli 1986; Pound et al. 2004) to predict the 1.3mm fluxes for a range of embedded luminosities (restricting to L<0.1 Lsun), density profiles, and extinctions. For sources at the distance of Ophiuchus, the typical flux at 1.3mm was greater than ~1 mJy, even for very compact (R ~ 300AU), very low mass objects (M ~ 0.5 M_Jupiter). Our existing ALMA and CARMA detections provide a consistent picture with the model results, with 1.3mm fluxes of a few to few 10s of mJy for sources at the mid to high end of the VeLLO luminosity ranges. As our Cycle 2 ALMA data show, the resultant spectral line S/N is sufficient to map the outflows. Furthermore, we wish to keep uniform S/N with our successful Cycle 2 observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Use the 1.3mm continuum to detect the dust emission from material in a circumstellar disk and/or inner envelope associated with a VeLLO. The emission can be used to estimate the mass of material in the disk or inner envelope. This material represents the reservoir of material that is likely to be accreted in the next 10,000 years and indicates the likely nature of the VeLLO.
Use the CO J=2-1 line to detect the outflow. The outflow confirms the VeLLO status of the source. A background AGN is expected to have a much broader CO line.

The time request for this science goal is set by the continuum sensitivity requirement of 0.07 mJy/beam at the 150 pc distance of Lupus. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection and Characterization of Sources in Lupus IV

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Very Low Luminosity Objects (VeLLOs) are young stellar sources that are defined by luminosities less than 0.1 solar luminosity and rising mid-infrared spectral energy distributions. But what exactly are they: brown dwarfs or low-mass stars in formation, systems exhibiting low accretion, extremely young objects? We propose to characterize the VeLLO class through observations of 1.3mm continuum and CO J=2-1 outflow emission of a sample of 21 likely candidates in the nearby Ophiuchus and Lupus molecular clouds. Combined with our successful Cycle-2 program, this survey is expected to triple the number of confirmed VeLLOs as well as extend the class to sources with even lower luminosities. Our observations will provide estimates of their inner envelope masses, and help address questions concerning the nature of VeLLOs.
